author: Edmunds Cars
text: The ID.4 experience is one of peaks and valleys; we love how it drives, but the user experience drives us up a wall. What's more important to you? Let us know in the comments below!

author: Aaron Christensen
text:
Thinking of purchasing a EV (maybe an id 4) but we are snowbirds and would be leaving it behind outside in the cold North Idaho winters.
Is storing it 4 months in the cold bad for the battery health, should that be left plugged in?

Any help would be appreciated, we can't seem to find any info on this subject.

Thanks!

text: I have the ID4 2023 model with 3.1 software and have no software issues. The volume it controled at the steering wheel, but if you insist on using the bar under the screen, just slide it and it doesn¬¥t matter where you hit it. Same with the temp control.

text: That it is similar to crappy ICEv is not a good thing.

author: Dionisio Ram√≠rez
text: I have an European 2021 ID.4 with 3.0 Over The Air software. It works great now. It is a good car that, nevertheless, had several noticeable issues at the beginning. There are no software bugs anymore and, for example, Travel Assist works great now: it follows the road curves very accurately and the steering wheel turns smoothly (in this aspect, comparable to the Tesla SFD). After 1 year and 4 month I can say that the car is worth it.

author: Bill Shoe
text: What a disaster

author: Jarod John
text: Have 33k miles on my 21 pro s and it's been an absolute nightmare. Worst car by far I've owned. Suspension issues, ac control module failed from factory, faulty 12 v battery, and infotainment system is absolute garbage. I know there is a planned update, but my wife got it on hers and it's a very lack luster update. The current issue is there is a recall pending for a software bug that may cause lost of propulsion during driving. On top of all that seats are wearing out and cracking despite not using them, and a similar story on leather steering wheel starting to crack. While everyones dealer will be different but the two dealers in my area have been slow and frequently have to bring vehicle in multiple times before issues are actually fixed. Extremely poor ownership experience overall.

author: Danny Briseno
text: Driven my ID.4 for 30k miles‚Ä¶.catch up

author: Car0917
text: it could be a consideration for purchasing because the price is cheaper and the specs are almost the same as competitors

author: Chris Lamb
text: I got one of these right before Christmas. I have 4450 miles on it and no software issues. Some things require more touches than they should, like changing stations on the radio, but not really the climate control. Just set it on auto and touch the ‚Äúbuttons‚Äù to raise and lower the temp. The travel assist works very well, once I‚Äôm on the highway, I don‚Äôt need to steer or work the pedals, and that‚Äôs with lots of curves and stop and go traffic. Where I live, teslas are extremely common, and I didn‚Äôt want the same thing as everyone else. You do give up is a little range, I have the awd and I only get about 265. It‚Äôs a good car if you want something different.

author: Scott Laughlin
text: I think being aware of the issues, I still feel Comfortable purchasing an AWD, Pro S this summer

author: Andrew Ibarra
text: I don't know why everyone freaks out about the window buttons. Every reviewer is always driving by themselves yet whining that they can't roll down the back windows easily... but why and who, when driving solo, needs to roll down the rear windows? I own an ID.4 and don't find it a bother at all. When my kids are in the car with me in the back, they can roll down the windows on their own.

author: Benjamin Schneider
text: With buttons on the ignition key to open all the windows, Volkswagen has been doing this for a long time. He was already with my Golf 3.

author: LexaPr0
text:
The disaster of an infotainment system is a dealbreaker. You interact with it just too much for phones to be disconnecting, mileage to be that far off, OTA updates that don‚Äôt end up being OTA.

It‚Äôs clear VW is still over their head in this department, which is nuts considering how long they‚Äôve been doing this.

text: I have a ID.4 2021 Pro S driving experience is amazing, quiet ride, no issues at all. Car is fantastic for everyday drive. Did 2 road-trips from Boca Raton, FL to Charlotte with no issues. It‚Äôs my first EV car moving from gas cars.

text: Have a 2023 ID.4 and absolutely love it. Has had zero issues, not even with software, drives great, has good range, charges great, roomy, and the newer software is much better.

author: Jo66hn
text:
We've just bought a 2023 ID.4 Pro and have driven it for about a month. The driving experience has been excellent. Smooth acceleration, nice handling and super quiet in the cabin. Build quality is excellent with no panel gaps or poor interior fit out. Apple Carplay and Android Auto have worked flawlessly.
That being said the UI isn't great. It has worked fine but it's just not very intuitive. If VW can come up with a UI that makes a little more sense then they have quite a car on their hands. All up we really love our ID.4.

text: In regards to the auto down feature with the windows‚Ä¶my 2016 Fusion SE with tech package has that and I did the same thing when I bought the car. Didn‚Äôt know it was enabled and must have had the key in my pocket while I napped. Woke up and wasn‚Äôt aware until the guy from my town‚Äôs city hall messaged me and told me. It was snowing that day.  Learned how to turn that off immediately and it‚Äôs been off since then. Probably handy down south when it is super hot but not in MN.
